# Arpeggio: Major in F (Shape: G)

## Description
An arpeggio is a musical technique where notes in a chord are played or sung in a sequence, one after the other, instead of simultaneously. The Major arpeggio in F (using the G shape) consists of the notes F, A, and C. When played in sequence, these notes create a bright and uplifting sound that is commonly used in various genres of music.

## Notes and Intervals
- F (Root / 1st)
- A (Major 3rd)
- C (Perfect 5th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Major arpeggio in F (using the G shape) is often used in genres such as pop, R&B, jazz, and classical music. It adds a sense of brightness, positivity, and resolution to musical compositions. This arpeggio is commonly heard in upbeat and cheerful songs, as well as in compositions that aim to evoke a sense of joy and optimism.

## Songs
Here are three songs that prominently feature the Major arpeggio in F (using the G shape):
1. "Hey Jude" by The Beatles
2. "Don't Stop Believin'" by Journey
3. "I Will Always Love You" by Whitney Houston
